bug.author: firstmover
bug.summary: Incorrect cache hit when argument is a list of float
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h1>Summary</denchmark-h>
Incorrect cache hit when argument is a list of float. <denchmark-h:h1>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
import streamlit as st
@st.cache() def _func(o): return o
def main():
for o in [[0.0, 1.0], [2.0, 3.0]]: print("o: {}".format(o)) ret_o = _func(o) print("ret_o: {}".format(ret_o))
for o in [[0, 1], [2, 3]]: print("o: {}".format(o)) ret_o = _func(o) print("ret_o: {}".format(ret_o))
if __name__ == "__main__": main() <denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior:</denchmark-h>
_func returns the argument o. In main loop, for each _func call o and ret_o should be identical. <denchmark-h:h2>Actual behavior:</denchmark-h>
Incorrect cache hit when o is a list of float. When o is a list of int, it works correctly. <denchmark-h:h2>Is this a regression?</denchmark-h>
I am not sure. I didn't try the old version. <denchmark-h:h1>Debug info</denchmark-h>
Streamlit version: 0.56.0 Python version: 3.7.4 conda OS version: Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS Browser version: Google Chrome 80.0.3987.116

comments.comment: Hi <denchmark-link:https://github.com/firstmover>@firstmover</denchmark-link> , This does seem to be a bug. Thanks for reporting it!

I just wanted to comment (as can be seen in <denchmark-link:https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues/1502>#1502</denchmark-link> ) that this bug only happens if the floats are integer-like, i.e. it does not happen with [1.0001, 2.0001, ...] but it does happen for [1.0, 2.0,...].
